awd_titl_txt: NSF Project Scoping Workshop: Towards Precise & Accurate Calculations of Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support a two-day Virtual NSF Project Scoping Workshop on the topic of "Precise and Accurate Calculations of Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay". Theoretical nuclear physics input is critical to the interpretation of experimental results that could demonstrate that neutrinos are their own antiparticles. As such, theoretical nuclear physics will play an important role in understanding the excess of matter over antimatter in the universe, one of outstanding grand challenges in modern science. This Project Scoping Workshop will provide a forum for the community of practitioners in this field to take stock of recent scientific advancements, identify current challenges, discuss opportunities to overcome those challenges, and map a way forward for the success of the experimental Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay projects. This project advances the goals outlined out in the 2015 LONG RANGE PLAN for NUCLEAR SCIENCE regarding “the timely development and deployment of a U.S.-led ton-scale neutrinoless double beta decay experiment.”

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Standard Model of Particle Physics explains all but a few of the phenomena observed in laboratories here on Earth. However, it does not explain why we live in a universe in which there is much more matter than anti-matter. The weakly interacting neutrino, the lightest particle in the standard model, may hold the key to this mystery.

In 1937 Italian physicist Ettore Majorana proposed an intriguing idea. Majorana hypothesized that there could be particles that are like the electrons, neutrons, and protons that make up atoms, but that are their own anti-particles. Some fundamental particles whose exchange produces forces  (e.g,  the photon) are their own anti-particle, but there “force carriers” have different properties than electrons, neutrons, and protons do. We now know that quarks and electrons cannot be their own anti-particle--and neither can the electron's heavy cousins, the muon and the tauon. The neutrino is thus the only fundamental particle that is not a force carrier that can be its own anti-particle. This is important because simulations  show that if neutrinos are actually  "Majorana particles” it would permit the generation of a significant matter-anti-matter asymmetry during the first minute of the universe’s existence. 

The only fesaible way to prove the neutrino is a Majorana particle is to measure a very rare decay mode of certain nuclei. While many nuclei undergo beta decay, a few (76Ge, 136Xe to name two examples) will only decay via "double beta decay". Beta decay is accompanied by neutrino emission, and double beta decay should see the nucleus spit out two neutrinos. If such a double beta decay were observed, but no neutrinos were emitted, it would tell us that the neutrino is a Majorana particle. 

But half lives for neutrinoless double beta decay are at least 1028 years. This is such a rare decay that, even if we wait a decade, only a few nuclei will decay within an entire ton of material. Experiments arounnd the world are now gearing up to do tests of Majorana's idea on this scale. 

This workshop brought together theorists who work to connect the properties of the hypothetical Majorana neutrino to the half life of different nuclei that could undergo neutrinoless double beta decay. Doing this reliably requires an understanding of the microscopic details of the beta decay that takes place deep inside a nucleus. The particular nature of the  mechanism that causes neutrinoless double beta decay also affects the decay rate. Making this connection therefore requires a team of theorists with expertise stretching all the way from Standard Model physics at attometer distance scales to the shapes of nuclei at the still incredibly small, but ten thousand times larger, distance scale of 10s of femtometers. 

Theoretical physicists with expertise spanning that range attended the workshop and talked about the work that is needed to make a reliable calculation  of this process a reality. The workshop also involved statisticians and physicists focused on uncertainty quantification of physics models. They helped the neutrinoless double beta decay experts work out ways to determine he uncertainty of their calculations. The result was a road map for calulations of neutrinoless double beta decay that are both precise--meaning that they give a number with a small uncertainty--and accurate, in that this quoted uncertainty on that number is reliable.

Such calculations are essential as ton-scale searches for neutrinoless double beta decay move from conception to reality and we face the prospect of determining exaclty how much material is needed to see this incredibly rare process. And, in the exciting event that such a search sees an unambiguous signal of neutrinoless double beta decay, the theoretical road map laid out at this workshop will be essential to understanding the implications of that signal for the matter-anti-matter asymmetry of the universe, and hence for the question of why there are enough electrons, and protons to build atoms and the complex moleculues that are the basis of human--and indeed all--life.
